prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: N2H+, DCO+, DCN, H2CO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Obtain maps of N2H+ and H2CO 4-3 transitions. DCO+ an DCN also observed as a probe of deuterium chemistry.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator will be configured with one baseband observing N2H+ J=3-2 with 0.065 km/s resolution. While our sensitivity estimate is based on binning by 3 of these channels, the N2H+ emission may be brighter than what is observe in TW Hya, therefore we are requesting a raw spectral resolution fine enough such that we can better map the velocities of the emission if signal to noise is sufficient at higher resolution. We are also observing four H2CO transitions in the upper side band with 0.14 km/s resolution. With the requested resolution we can resolve the lines and map their kinematic structure. The linewidths are expected to be ~+/-2 km/s due to disk rotation; thus, the lines will be well-resolved. We are then using another baseband to observe DCO+ J=4-3 and DCN J=4-3 as a complementary probe of temperature and deuterium chemistry in the disks. We are using spectral averaging to obtain a velocity resolution of 0.12 km/s, sufficient to resolve the lines and kinematics. Finally, the remaining baseband will be configured for 2 GHz continuum observations, probing the dust emission of the disks.

The angular resolution requested is high enough such that N2H+, and other line emission can be resolved in the disk. Moreover, the resolution is high enough such that the inner radius of the N2H+ emission can be resolved, if their emission properties are comparable to TW Hya. While the inner radius of N2H+ was 25 AU toward TW Hya, our sources are higher luminositiy and will have a minimum N2H+ radius of 47 AU; 94 AU in diameter. Our requested beam size gives a spatial resolution of 70 AU in Taurus, therefore we will be able to resolve the inner radii of N2H+ emission. The largest angular scale of 5" (700 AU) is chosen such that we will be sensitive to the continuum emission from the entire Keplerian disk (largest is ~600 AU), as well as the more possibly more-extended, low-velocity emission that is associated with the outer disks and inner infalling envelope of these sources.

Our sensitivity estimate is driven by the need to detect the N2H+ (J=3-2) transition. The TW Hya N2H+ map had a sensitivity of 30 mJy/beam for the N2H+ J=4-3 transition. RADEX calculations for a density of 1x10^10 cm^-3, excitation temperature of 25 K, column density of 1 x 10^14 cm^-2, and a line width of 2 km/s indicate that the J=4-3 line is nearly equivalent in brightness to the J=3-2 line. Thus, we scaled the sensitivity of the TW Hya observations (30 mJy/beam; 0.1 km/s channels) to the distance of Taurus (140 pc) versus 54 pc for TW Hya; we will also bin our channels to 0.195 km/s. Thus our required sensitivity is 6.22 mJy/beam and our beam size is only ~0.1" smaller than the TW Hya observations, meaning that our surface brightness sensitivity will also be comparable.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H13CN, H13CO+, HDO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map H13CN molecule, in addition to H13CO+ and HDO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We have configured baseband 1 to observe the H13CO+ and H13CN lines using 58 MHz bandwidth and each use a factor of 2 spectral averaging, without significantly changing the velocity resolution; the velocit resolution is ~0.08 km/s and we expect to further bin by 2 channels depending on the signal to noise of the sourcesThe linewidths are expected to be ~+/-2 km/s due to disk rotation; thus, the lines will be well-resolved. Two other basebands are configured for continuum observations and the remaining baseband is configured for observation of the HDO 2_11-2_12 line as a complementary probe of water deuteration. Detections of this line would further motivate future proposals based on the D/H ratio of water.

The resolution is chosen such that the spatial resolution of the observations is 70 AU, enabling us to differentiate between structures in the outer disk and inner disk for all the proposed sources; radii are of order 100 AU for all sources. Moreover, in channels where the emission is point-like and have a signal-to-noise >3, we will be able to centroid the emission by the factor beamsize/signal-to-noise. This means that we can determine the position of line emission to at least ~0.16" or 22 AU (at highest velocities) and even better toward line-center where emission is brighter. The largest angular scale of 5" (700 AU) is chosen such that we will be sensitive to the continuum emission from the entire Keplerian disk (largest is ~600 AU), as well as the more possibly more-extended, low-velocity emission that is associated with the outer disks and inner infalling envelope of these sources.

The sensitivity of this science goal is driven by the detection of H13CN toward the disk in the protostars. We require a sensitivity of 9 mJy/beam to detect H13CN with 4-sigma confidence in 0.16 km/s channels (binning the 0.08 km/s raw channels) in the high-velocity line wings. This estimate is based on Cycle 1 observations and detection of H13CN 4-3 within the disk of the Class 0/I protostar L483 (Jorgensen et al. in prep); the line flux density at its lowest level is ~36 mJy/beam/channel ~3 km/s from line center; RADEX calculations indicate that the H13CN 4-3 and H13CN 3-2 lines should have comparable brightness at a temperature of 40 K, density of 1 x 10^9 cm^-3, column of 1x10^14 cm^-2 and 2 km/s line width. With this sensitivity, H13CO+ 3-2 should also be strongly detected on the scales of the disks.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CN, H2CO, C17O, HDO
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Map CN N=2-1 transitions, in addition to C17O, ortho-H2CO, and HDO.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Our correlator setup is configured to observe all the transitions of CN (located in 3 clusters at ~226 GHz), ortho-H2CO, C17O, and Methanol. Baseband 1 uses 2 - 117 MHz to cover two of the CN clusters and Baseband 2 covers the last cluster of CN lines with a 58 MHz window, in addition to H2CO and C17O. The CN lines are observed with 0.16 km/s resolution, this spectral resolution is sufficient to resolve the lines which will be between +/- 2 km/s wide (depending on the rotation velocities and location in the disks). The ortho-H2CO and C17O lines are observed for added kinematic value; C17O is the most optically thin CO isotopologue. The disk rotation goes out to ~2 - 3 km/s in some sources, and H2CO and C17O can offer a complementary view of the disk kinematics and enable us to determine how optically thin or thick C18O is. We are also observing the cluster of methanol lines at 241 GHz with a single 234 MHz window with 0.3 km/s channels. The methanol lines are expected to be broad (1 km/s), if they trace an inner disk/hot corino component in the protostars, thus the spectral resolution is sufficient.

The resolution is chosen such that the spatial resolution of the observations is 70 AU, enabling us to differentiate between structures in the outer disk and inner disk. All the proposed sources have radii of order 100 AU for all sources. Moreover, in channels where the emission is point-like and we have a signal-to-noise of 10, we will be able to centroid the emission by the factor beamsize/signal-to-noise. This means that we can likely determine the position of line emission to ~0.05" or 7 AU. The largest angular scale of 5" (700 AU) is chosen such that we will be sensitive to the continuum emission from the entire Keplerian disk (largest is ~600 AU), as well as the possibly more-extended, low-velocity emission that is associated with the outer disks and inner infalling envelope of these sources.

The signal to noise calculations are based on the expected flux densities per channel for CN. CN has been only been observed (and detected) with an interferometer toward one protostar, IRAS 04302+2247, with the PdBI (Guilloteau et al. 2014). The line flux densities were ~80 mJy/beam in ~0.2 km/s channels. Thus, with the requested sensitivity to detect the brightest CN lines with at least 10-sigma significance is 8.8 mJy/beam, after accounting for our narrow channel width of 0.16 km/s. Moreover, because we are observing all the hyperfine transitions, we can average the lines together to boost the signal to noise by a factor of 2. Because of the disk rotation, we will only observe molecular line emission from one side of the disk in a given velocity channel, and because at > 1km/s velocities, a given Keplerian velocity corresponds to a specific radius in the disk, making the line emission from most channels point-like.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: H2CO, C18O
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Observe H2CO J=3-2 lines at ~218.5 GHz along with some complementary tracers.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Within the first baseband, we are observing three H2CO lines and C18O at 0.168 km/s resolution and 58 MHz bandwidth. This spectral resolution is sufficient to resolve the lines, which will have velocity wings out to +/- 2 km/s (depending on the rotation velocities and location of the molecules in the disks. Baseband 2 will observe SO 5-4, 13CO, H13CO and c-C3H2 with 0.168 km/s resolution. These are all complementary kinematic tracers that have not been observed at such high angular resolution toward these sources and will likely offer better detections of the disk rotation than previous observations. c-C3H2 has been found to preferentially trace the envelope rather than disk toward L1527 and this may also be the case for other sources in Taurus. The remaining basebands will be configured for continuum observation.

The resolution is chosen such that the raw resolution of the observations is 70 AU, enabling us to differentiate between structures in the outer disk and inner disk for all the proposed sources because radii are of order 100 AU for all sources. Moreover, in channels where the emission is point-like and we have a signal-to-noise of 5, we will be able to centroid the emission by the factor beamsize/signal-to-noise. This means that we can likely determine the position of line emission to ~0.1" or 14 AU. The largest angular scale of 5" (700 AU) is chosen such that we will be sensitive to the continuum emission from the entire Keplerian disk (largest is ~600 AU), as well as the possibly more-extended, low-velocity emission that is associated with the outer disks and inner infalling envelope of these sources.

Ortho-H2CO 5_15-4_14 (351 GHz) was previously detected in the disk of L1527 (Sakai et al. 2014). The ~2 km/s line wings that trace the disk have intensities of ~ 100 mJy/beam in 0.1 km/s channels. Assuming an H2CO ortho to para ratio of 3:1 (e.g., Kahane et al. 1984), the para line intensities may be as much as 3x weaker or ~33 mJy/beam. This is likely a conservative estimate since the 5_15-4_14 is likely optically thick and the ortho-to-para ratio may be ~1.6 rather than 3 (Jorgensen et al. 2005). Thus, conservatively estimating the minimum line flux densities to be 33 mJy/beam/channel, in order to achieve a signal-to-noise of 5 at ~2 km/s from line center, probing ~50 AU radii we need to integrate to a sensitivity of 8.5 mJy/beam in 0.16 km/s channels. Because of the disk rotation, we will only observe molecular line emission from one side of the disk in a given velocity channel, and because at > 1km/s velocities, a given Keplerian velocity corresponds to a specific radius in the disk, making the line emission from most channels point-like. The requested intensitiy will be more than sufficient for C18O, given that it will have comparable sensitivity to the Ohashi et al. (2014) data at higher resolution.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: Embedded disks form during the star formation process due to angular momentum conservation of infalling gas. However, the physical conditions of these embedded, forming disks are very uncertain, while more-evolved proto-planetary disks are better characterized. Embedded disks tend to be more massive, but gas temperatures and the level of UV irradiation are unconstrained. We will characterize the disk temperatures and incident radiation fields by observing a suite of diagnostic molecular lines toward 4 embedded disks in Taurus (D~140 pc). To characterize the disk temperatures, we will observe the H2CO J=3-2 and J=4-3 transitions, using the line ratios to determine the gas temperatures and density. Observations N2H+ J=3-2 will then determine whether or not embedded disks have a cold midplane (T < ~25 K) where CO is frozen-out. The radiation field incident upon the disks will be characterized with ratio of CN/H13CN molecular line emission as a function of radius; CN is a direct product of HCN photodissociation. These diagnostic probes will enable the initial conditions for proto-planetary disk evolution (and possibly planet formation) to be characterized for the first time.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:relatedProposals: 2015.1.00096.S, Characterizing the Kinematic Structure of VLA-Detected Protostellar Disk Candidates, John Tobin
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2012.1.00193.S, Measuring the Mass of the Class 0 Protostar L1527 via Disk Rotation, John Tobin 2012.1.01069.S, Mapping the Envelopes of Edge-on Protostars in Orion, Will Fischer 2014.1.00209.S, The Stellar Masses and Disk Properties of Class I Protostars: Edge-on Disks in Orion , John Tobin
